Award.AwardTitle: Analysis and computation of partial differential equations in Mechanics and related fields
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mazzucato
1312727

This project focuses on the analysis of partial differential equations arising in continuum mechanics and related fields, such as statistical mechanics and probability. Both theoretical and computational aspects are addressed. Its aim is to help advance our understanding of physical phenomena in many-particle systems and impact real-life applications. Three main areas of investigation are considered.
(a) Incompressible fluid mechanics: boundary layers for linearized flows and helically-symmetric flows are studied.
(b) Elasticity: the principal Investigator continues to model elasticity in polyhedral domains and to develop suitable numerical methods, in particular the Generalized Finite Element Method (GFEM); she is investigating how to obtain size estimates of inclusions from boundary measurements.
(c) Solution methods for evolution equations: the investigator is further developing Green's function methods for parabolic equations, in particular Fokker-Planck equations; she also continues her work on a wave-packet solution method for variable-speed scattering problems, with applications to seismic imaging.
Common themes, such as the investigation of the effect of boundaries and interfaces on continuum systems, and the use of specific techniques, such as scaling and localization, make the project a cohesive research program. Employing refined analytical tools, microlocal and harmonic analysis in particular, is warranted by the complexity of the problems studied, which feature nonlinearities in the partial differential equations, ill-posedness and instabilities, and singular geometries.

The aim of this project is to advance our knowledge of complex phenomena occurring in the mechanics of fluids and elastic solids, by utilizing a rigorous analysis of the underlying mathematical models and by devising efficient, yet accurate, computational tools to simulate them. Some of these phenomena, such as turbulence in fluids, are a common occurrence, yet they still lack a thorough understanding. A relevant trait of the project is the interplay between theoretical and computational methods, with each providing its own avenue for investigation that can shed light on different aspects of the same phenomenon. Progress on each part of the project has the potential to impact real-life applications. Vorticity created by viscous flows at container walls enhances mixing and transport in fluids with applications for example to climate and environmental modeling, and industrial processes (part a) of the project). Helically-symmetric flows arise, for instance, in modeling of blood flow (part a)). Problems with interfaces appear naturally in a variety of applications, such as determining the elastic properties of composite materials and modeling of biological processes (part(b) of the project). Imaging by elastic waves is used as a non-invasive medical diagnostic tool and in probing the earth's interior, that is, in seismic imaging, for earthquake prediction (parts (b) and (c) of the project). Parabolic equations of the Fokker-Planck type arise in probability with applications, for example, to plasma physics and economics (part (c) of the project). The project provides training opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary  aim of the project  is to advance our knowledge of  complex physical systems, in particular the motion of fluids and the behavior of elastic solids, but combining a rigorous mathematical analysis of the models describing the system with efficient, yet accurate, computational tools. 

The project was comprised of three main parts: a) analysis of incompressible fluids flows at low viscosity; b) mechanics of composite materials; d) solution methods for evolution equations, which describe the response in time of complex systems to applied stimuli. The main outcomes for each of the three parts follow.

For part a) of the project, the Principal Investigator (PI) and her collaborators considered two related problems. the first concerns the behavior of incompressible fluids at very low viscosity near rigid walls. This is a challenging problem, because viscous fluids stick to surfaces, creating drag, while inviscid fluids do not. Hence, near walls, in the so-called viscous layer, the fluid experiences large fluctuations, which lead to instabilities and the onset of turbulence, such as in the turbulent wake of an airplane. These instabilities can for example be responsible for stalling in airplanes, so it is crucial to understand how to model and predict them. The PI's work has provided some of the very few known examples where a rigorous mathematical analysis of the viscous layer is possible. These  are flows in pipes and channels with special symmetry. In particular, a rigorous quantification of how much  vorticity (i.e., swirls) is created in the flow by the walls was obtained. The second problem concerns the construction and analysis of flows that optimally  mix a passive tracer advected by the flow, such as nutrients in a stream. Characterizing how well a flow mixes is important in many applied fields, from environmental science (e.g. pollutant dispersal) to climate change (e.g. changes in CO2 concentration in the atmosphere), for example. The PI and her collaborators were able to construct optimal mixers when the flow has to satisfy physically-based constraints, such as an energy and power budgets. These are among the very few rigorous examples available in the mathematics literature.

For part b) of the project, the PI and her collaborators have tackled the study of both static (e.g. elasticity) and dynamic (e.g. heat conduction) problems in composite materials, the shape of which  has  singularities, such as cracks and corners. The presence of these singularities has a deep impact on the response of the material. For example near the tip of a crack in an elastic solid, the stress can become infinite. The PI's contributions in this area has been a simplified approach to the study of the material behavior near the singularities, which is particularly suited to an accurate implementation of certain numerical methods, called the  Finite Element Method and the Generalized Finite Element Method, to simulate the material response. These methods are widely used by engineers.

For part c) of the project, the PI and her collaborators have continued the analysis and implementation of novel iterative methods to solve evolution equations that arise in probability. Solutions to these equations, called Fokker-Planck or Kolmogorov equations, give the probability of certain events for complex systems that experience noise. These equations are used, for example, in financial mathematics to price options of contingent claims on risky assets. The method developed by the PI uses a simplified (reduced) system to  model the full system, taking advantage of the particular structure and symmetry of the full system, and lead to efficient computational methods. The error is reduced by utilizing the reduced system repeatedly. Having a fast solver is especially important when estimating unknown model parameters in noisy systems.

The results of the projects have been broadly disseminated by the PI to the mathematics community in the form of seminars at conferences and professional meetings,  through mutual exchanges between the PI and other researchers, and through the organization of focused workshops and summer schools. The project has also provided training and professional development opportunities, thus enhancing its broader impacts. Two PhD students of the PI have worked on problems directly related to the project. Five undergraduate students  were supervised by the PI in research experiences related to the project. Two of the students supervised by the PI are from under-represented groups, contributing to the diversity of the project personnel.
